The development of highly efficient and recyclable bifunctional photoredox catalysts is extremely promising for organic synthesis. In this study, a novel kind of bifunctional metal-organic framework (MOF) based catalysts were prepared through the in-situ incorporation of the L-proline moiety into the MOF network and followed by the anchoring of dye molecules via a solvothermal process. These catalysts exhibited versatile catalytic activity in the visible light triggered α-alkylation of aldehydes and cross-dehydrogenative coupling reactions between N-aryl tetrahydroquinolines and ketones. The control experiments revealed enhanced synergy existed between the two kinds of catalytic active centers confined in the porous framework, resulting in significantly enhanced catalytic activities while maintaining comparable enantioselectivities to the corresponding homogeneous catalytic systems. Furthermore, the bifunctional catalysts showed high stability and reusability over five consecutive cycles with only a slight decrease in activity. Based on the experimental results, a plausible reaction mechanism over the present bifunctional catalyst was proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MOFS Photocatalysis Bifunctional catalyst Alkylation Cross-dehydrogenative coupling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Visible light photoredox catalysis has attracted increasing interest as a convenient and sustainable strategy for organic synthesis [1–7]. The pioneering work of MacMillan et al. in 2008 for the direct enantioselective α-alkylation of aldehydes by combining the photoredox catalyst Ru(bpy)3 2+ and the organocatalyst imidazolidinone triggered a research upsurge of photocatalytic asymmetric synthesis [8]. Significant research efforts have focused on developing this merged approach and a variety of homogeneous photocatalytic systems, typically with noble-metal polypyridyl complexes and organic dyes as photocatalysts, have been developed [9–12]. These combined catalytic systems can enable significant organic transformations that cannot be accomplished by either catalyst alone, and have driven significant progress in chemical synthesis; however, the potential residual toxicity and high cost of the photocatalysts significantly limit their practical applications [9]. Consequently, significant efforts have been devoted in the past decade to the development of heterogeneous photoredox catalysts based on different materials such as metal oxides/sulfides [13–19], carbon nitrides [20], organic porous polymers [21], metal nanoclusters [22–25], and covalent organic frameworks [26]. Combining an additional organocatalyst, can construct an effective dual catalytic system where the two active components operate independently. Despite their high performance, such dual systems still face challenges in the separating and recycling of the organic molecular catalysts. Compared to dual systems, bifunctional systems, which incorporate both photo- and organocatalytic components into a single matrix, can reduce complexity and facilitate practical operation. In this regard, a few heterogeneous bifunctional visible-light-driven organocatalysts have been developed. Duan et al. reported both non-interpenetrated and interpenetrated bifunctional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) catalysts containing a triphenylamine photoactive component and a chiral pyrrolidin-2-ylimidazole organocatalyst for highly efficient α-alkylation reactions and β-carbonyl functionalization, respectively [27]. Tang et al. developed a series of bifunctional chiral MOFs constructed by coordinating a prolinal-based chiral photoredox ligand with different metal ions, providing tunable catalytic activity for α-alkylation relying on metal ions [28]. Zhang et al. prepared a bifunctional organic sponge photocatalyst integrating an enamine organocatalytic center and rose bengal into a polydimethylsiloxane sponge, which showed high catalytic activity for the cross-dehydrogenative coupling reactions of tertiary amines with ketones [29]. An amide-based bifunctional porous organic framework was constructed to anchor rose bengal and L-proline through stepwise solid phase peptide synthesis, and the resulting bifunctional catalyst could effectively catalyze the visible-light mediated oxidative Mannich reactions [30]. Despite these elegant pioneering works, the development of heterogeneous bifunctional photo-organocatalysts remains limited, and more convenient and efficient synthetic strategies are highly desirable. UiO-type MOFs, composed of Zr6 clusters and dicarboxylate linkers, are renowned for their prominent chemical, mechanical and thermal stability, making them promising platforms for heterogeneous catalysis [31–36]. Additionally, the flexibility of secondary building units and dicarboxylate linkers makes it convenient to incorporate different catalytic sites into one single framework. Herein, we present a concise strategy for constructing a versatile UiO-based bifunctional photo-organocatalyst by the in-situ introduction of L-proline during the synthesis of the MOF material and followed by dye functionalization via solvothermal treatment. The versatile catalytic ability of the bifunctional catalysts was evaluated in both the α-alkylation of aldehydes and cross-dehydrogenative coupling reactions of N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinolines with ketones under visible light irradiation, demonstrating broad substrate scope, high efficiency, and good reusability. Moreover, we demonstrated enhanced synergy between the two kinds of catalytic active sites in these MOFs catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 99 %), L-proline (99 %), zirconium(IV) oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, ZrO2 + HfO2 ≥ 35 %), Eosin B (99 %), Rose Bengal (99 %), and 2,6-lutidine (99 %) were purchased from Heowns Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl4, 98 %, HfCl4 < 2 %) was obtained from Aladdin Reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. Eosin Y (99 %) was provided by Shanghai Dibai Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Ethanol (99 %), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99 %), tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99 %), acetonitrile (CH3CN, 99 %), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 99 %), and acetone (99 %) were supplied by Tianjin Bohua Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of L-proline-modified UiO-66 (UiO-LP) UiO-LP was synthesized following a reported procedure with slight modifications [37]. ZrOCl2·8H2O (483 mg, 1.5 mmol), H2BDC (1.25 g, 7.5 mmol) and L-proline (863 mg, 7.5 mmol) were added into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave containing 20 mL of DMSO. The mixture was sonicated until complete dissolution of all solid reagents. The autoclave was then sealed and kept in a preheated oven at 90 °C for 3 days. After being cooled to room temperature, the solid was collected by centrifugation, washed successively with DMF (3 × 20 mL) and THF (3 × 20 mL), and dried under vacuum at 90 °C for 24 h to get UiO-LP. For comparison, the pure UiO-66 was synthesized according to the previously reported literature based on ZrCl4 and H2BDC [38]. 2.3 Synthesis of dye-functionalized UiO-LP UiO-LP (1.0 mmol) and organic dye (0.1 mmol) were added to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave containing ethanol (20 mL), then the mixture was sonicated for 5 min to form a homogeneous suspension. Subsequently, the autoclave was transferred to an oven preheated at 120 °C and held for 12 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the solid was collected by centrifugation, washed repeatedly with ethanol to remove unbound dye, and then dried in vacuum at 90 °C for 24 h. The resulting specimens functionalized with Eosin Y, Eosin B and Rose Bengal were designated as UiO-LP-EY, UiO-LP-EB and UiO-LP-RB, respectively. For comparison, Eosin Y-loaded UiO-66, denoted as UiO-EY, was also synthesized with the same process except that UiO-66 was used in place of UiO-LP. 2.4 General procedure for the α-alkylation of aldehydes A mixture of MOFs catalyst (0.05 mmol, based on L-proline), aldehyde (1.0 mmol), the corresponding bromide (0.5 mmol), 2,6-lutidine (1.0 mmol), and dry DMF (1.0 mL) was charged to a 25 mL Schlenk tube equipped with a magnetic stir bar and a rubber plug. The reaction mixture was degassed via three freeze-pump-thaw cycles using liquid nitrogen, and backfilled with nitrogen. The reaction was performed under stirring and irradiation with green LED light (6 W) at room temperature, and the reaction progress was monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC) (Sil G/UV 254). Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethyl acetate (3 × 2.0 mL), and the combined organic extracts were washed with aqueous HCl (1.0 M, 1.0 mL) and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The crude product was obtained by concentration under reduced pressure and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel with petroleum ether/diethyl ether (10:1, v/v). 2.5 General procedure for the cross-dehydrogenative coupling reactions of N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinolines and ketones A mixture of MOFs catalyst (0.02 mmol, based on L-proline), N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinoline (0.1 mmol), the corresponding ketone (1.0 mmol), and CH3CN (1.0 mL) was charged to a 20 mL reaction tube equipped with a magnetic bar. The reaction mixture was stirred in air and irradiated under green LED light (6 W) at room temperature, and was monitored by TLC (Sil G/UV 254). Upon completion of the reaction, the MOFs catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethyl acetate (3 × 2.0 mL); the combined organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (20:1, v/v). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the materials The crystal structure of as-synthesized UiO-LP as determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 1 a), was confirmed to be consistent with that of the bare UiO-66 [38]. All the dye-functionalized specimens maintained the structure of UiO-LP though a slight decrease in XRD peak intensities was observed. The results of N2 sorption analysis revealed that all MOF samples exhibited type I isotherms with a steep N2 uptake in the lower relative pressure range of P/P0 < 0.01 (Fig. 1b), indicating that UiO-LP possessed a microporous structure, as expected, and that this structure was well preserved. UiO-LP exhibited a high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of 885 m2g-1. Upon dye functionalization, a slight decrease in BET surface area was observed (Table S1), likely due to the encapsulation of dye molecules within the UiO-LP nanopores. The Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy analysis was used to investigate chemical compositions of prepared MOF specimens (Fig. 2 ). The FTIR spectrum of UiO-LP exhibited characteristic peaks corresponding to both L-proline and UiO-66 (Figure S1). The peaks near 2900 and 1440 cm-1 were attributed to CH stretching and deformation vibrations of methylene groups belonging to L-proline, and the peak at around 810 cm-1 is due to characteristic vibrations of para-disubstituted benzene rings in the UiO-66 framework. The broad peak around 1600 cm-1 could be ascribed to asymmetric stretching vibrations of bidentate COO groups derived from both H2BDC and L-proline, along with a broad symmetric COO stretching vibration peak at approximately 1400 cm-1. All the dye-functionalized specimens, with low loadings of dyes, exhibited FTIR spectra similar to UiO-LP, except for the presence of two new weak peaks at 980 cm-1 and 1040 cm-1, indicating successful anchoring of dye molecules onto UiO-LP [39]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was acquired to characterize the chemical states and functional groups of the as-synthesized samples. The survey-scan spectrum of UiO-LP-EY confirmed the presence of Zr, C, O, N, and Br, consistent with the composition of the Zr clusters, L-proline, and Eosin Y (EY) (Fig. 3 and S6). As shown in the high-resolution Zr 3d spectrum (Fig. 3a), the peaks located at ∼185.1 and 182.8 eV correspond to Zr 3d3/2 and Zr 3d5/2, respectively, matching those reported for the Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster in UiO-66 type MOFs [40]. In the high-resolution C 1 s spectrum, the peaks observed at approximately 284.8 eV, 286.4 eV, and 288.7 eV were assigned to C–H/C–C, C–O, and O–C=O species, respectively (Fig. 3b) [39]. The N 1 s spectrum exhibited a single peak at 399.5 eV, attributed to the C–N bond from the L-proline moiety (Figure S6c). Peaks located at ∼71.3 and 70.4 eV corresponded to Br 3d3/2 and Br 3d5/2, respectively (Fig. 3d) [41]. The O 1 s region displayed two main contributions at ∼531.8 eV and ∼533.6 eV, corresponding to O–C=O and –OH groups, respectively, which originate from the BDC linker, L-proline, and EY molecules (Fig. 3c) [42]. Notably, the absence of the Zr–O bond signal—typically observed at ∼530.2 eV in pristine UiO-66—along with the enhanced intensities of the O–C=O and –OH peaks, indicates substantial surface coverage by L-proline and EY molecules, suggesting their successful chemical grafting onto the UiO framework. The field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis showed that UiO-LP exhibits a near-spherical morphology with particle sizes of 0.5–1.0 μm, which was well preserved after dye anchoring (Fig. 4 ). The prepared MOF specimens were acid-digested and subjected to 1H NMR analysis to further confirm the composition of the specimens (Figure S2). The 1H NMR spectrum of the digested UiO-LP showed characteristic signals at 8.05 ppm (benzene ring protons of BDC linkers) and between 4.32 and 1.88 ppm (CH₂ and CH groups of L-proline) (Figure S2a), providing direct evidence for the successful incorporation of L-proline into UiO-LP. The molar ratio of BDC linker to L-proline moiety in UiO-LP was determined to be approximately 1:1 by integration of the peaks centered at 8.05 and 2.26 ppm. No signals corresponding to acylated L-proline were detected. On dye-functionalization, new peaks corresponding to the dye molecules appeared between 7.85 and 7.74 ppm in the 1H NMR spectra of functionalized UiO-LP specimens (Figure S2b-d), verifying their successful immobilization of dye molecules onto UiO-LP. Dye functionalization had a marginal influence on the ratio of BDC to L-proline moiety was observed for all the functionalized samples, with dye loadings measured at approximately 0.05 mol per mol of BDC. Based on these results, representative structural diagrams of UiO-LP and UiO-LP-EY are depicted in Fig. 5 . Fig. 6 a shows the diffuse reflectance ultraviolet-visible (DRUV–vis) spectra of bare and functionalized UiO-LP specimens. The optical absorption edge of UiO-LP is located at approximately 320 nm. The loading of dye molecules endows the materials with strong visible-light absorption and a red-shifted absorption edge near 600 nm, suggesting potential for visible-light photocatalytic activity. Notably, Figure S3 shows that, compared to the free dye molecules, the corresponding functionalized MOF samples exhibited significantly different absorption profiles in the range of visible light, having a broad and strong absorption peak from about 470 nm to 580 nm that is very close to the wavelength range of green light. The coordination bonds between the COO of dye molecules and Zr atoms from UiO-LP facilitate photogenerated electron transfer from excited dye to UiO-LP framework, improving charge separation efficiency and enhancing light absorption of dye functionalized MOFs. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra was performed to further investigate the charge transfer and separation behavior of the synthesized MOF materials. As illustrated in Fig. 6b, upon excitation at 465 nm, the emission peak of UiO-LP-EY was significantly quenched compared to that of the physically mixed UiO-LP/EY sample. This pronounced quenching effect suggests that photogenerated electrons from the EY molecules in UiO-LP-EY are efficiently transferred to the UiO-LP framework, thereby suppressing the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers. These results confirm that the chemical bonding between EY and UiO-LP exerts a distinctly different influence on the photophysical properties compared to mere physical adsorption. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The catalytic activity of the prepared MOF materials were first evaluated in the α-alkylation of aldehydes which involves both photoredox catalysis and organocatalysis. This redox process involves single-electron reduction and oxidation steps, both requiring a photocatalyst with appropriate redox potentials. The α-alkylation of hydrocinnamic aldehyde with diethyl bromomalonate was selected as a model reaction. As summarized in Table S2, all the dye-functionalized MOF catalysts were active for the reaction affording the target alkylation product under irradiation with green LED light at room temperature, among which UiO-LP-EY exhibited the highest activity, affording the product in 83 % isolated yield within 24 h. The high activity of UiO-LP-EY is likely associated with its superior light absorption in the range of 480–560 nm (Fig. 5). Almost no reaction was observed under dark conditions, confirming that light irradiation is essential for efficient alkylation (Table S2, entry 5). For comparison, UiO-LP was also used to catalyze the reaction and only trace amounts of product were detected under identical conditions,attributed to its poor visible-light absorption (Table S2, entry 1). In addition, UiO-EY, which was without pre-functionalization with L-proline, exhibited no catalytic activity for the model reaction (Table S2, entry 6). These results indicate that both the proline units and the dye moieties in the dye-functionalized UiO-LP catalysts are essential for the catalytic activity for the alkylation reaction. Furthermore, a control experiment with the mechanical mixture of UiO-LP and free Eosin Y as the catalyst afforded a significantly lower product yield (31 %) compared to UiO-LP-EY (Table S2, entry 7), even with a prolonged reaction time of 72 h. Even when a homogeneous catalytic system with L-proline and Eosin Y as catalysts was adopted, afforded lower activity (69 % yield) than UiO-LP-EY (Table S2, entry 8). These results highlight the superior synergistic effect between the confined proline and dye moieties in MOFs, which is facilitated by efficient electron transfer between dye molecules and the MOFs surface. Subsequently, the substrate scope of the catalyst system was investigated based on UiO-LP-EY. As shown in Table 1 , the α-alkylation of a variety of aldehydes with bromides over UiO-LP-EY exhibited good activity, affording the desired products in 73–88 % yields. Both hydrocinnamic aldehyde and various aliphatic aldehydes with different carbon chain lengths were smoothly converted to the corresponding alkylation products. Various diethylbromomalonates and bromoacetophenones could be employed as the alkylating reagent, and the electronic properties of the para-substituent in bromoacetophenones showed no significant influence on the reaction results. These results suggest that the present MOF catalyst system exhibits good photocatalytic and organocatalytic activity. Though adopting a simple chiral amine, the MOF catalyst exhibited modest enantioselectivity for the model reaction, affording the product with 20 % enantiomeric excess (ee) which was comparable to that achieved with the homogeneous system (Table S2, entry 8). The slightly higher ee value of UiO-LP-EY compared to the homogeneous system may be attributed to the confined chiral environment within the MOF pores, thus enhancing the stereochemical outcome by pre-organizing the transition state, which is consistent with previous reports on chiral MOFs for asymmetric catalysis [27,28]. The moderate enantioselectivity of the product may be attributed to the limited chiral induction ability of the enamine intermediate formed by L-proline and the relatively open active-site geometry. The recycling experiments showed that UiO-LP-EY exhibited good stability and reusability for the α-alkylation reaction, with only a slight decrease in yield after five successive cycles (Fig. 7 a). XRD and SEM analyses of the used catalyst revealed that the UiO-LP-EY catalyst retained its structural integrity upon the durability test (Fig. 7b and S4). The ¹H NMR analysis of UiO-LP-EY after five consecutive catalytic cycles revealed a n(BDC):n(L-proline):n(EY) ratio of 1:0.94:0.05 (Figure S5). This represents a slight decrease in both components compared to the initial ratio of the freshly prepared sample (1:0.993:0.0575). This suggests that the loss of L-proline and EY is likely responsible for the concomitant decrease in catalytic activity. Inspired by the successful application of the catalyst system for the α-alkylation of aldehydes, its catalytic performance was further evaluated in the cross-dehydrogenative coupling reaction of N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinolines with ketones. The model reaction between N-phenyl tetrahydroisoquinoline and acetone proceeded smoothly over the dye-functionalized catalysts under air upon irradiation with green LED light at room temperature (Table S3). UiO-LP-EY exhibited the highest activity, affording the coupling product in 88 % yield within 24 h (Table S3, entry 3). The dramatically decreased yield of control experiments confirmed that UiO-LP was inactive for the coupling reaction (Table S3, entry 4) and oxygen was is essential for the reaction to proceed (Table S3, entry 5). The broad substrate scope of the catalyst system was demonstrated by the successful synthesis a diversity of corresponding coupling products (Table 2 ). N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinolines bearing various electron-donating or electron-withdrawing substituents on the aryl ring reacted efficiently with acetone to afford the target products in good to excellent yields (79–93 %). In addition to aliphatic ketones, alicyclic ketones were also compatible and successfully converted to the corresponding products with satisfactory yields (70–72 %). 3.3 Reaction mechanism Based on the Tauc plot (Fig. 8 a), the optical bandgap of UiO-LP was estimated to be 4.02 eV. Mott-Schottky analysis (Fig. 8b) indicated a conduction band (CB) edge potential of −0.79 eV vs NHE. Accordingly, the valence band (VB) edge potential was calculated to be approximately 3.23 eV vs NHE. Eosin Y possesses a HOMO energy level (−0.82 eV vs NHE) that is more negative than the CB of UiO-LP (−0.79 eV vs NHE), and a LUMO energy level (+1.03 eV vs NHE) that is less positive than the VB of UiO-LP (+3.23 eV vs NHE) [43]. On the basis of the aforementioned results, plausible mechanisms for both alkylation and cross-dehydrogenative coupling are proposed. As depicted in Fig. 9 a, upon visible-light irradiation, the Eosin Y moiety in UiO-LP-EY is excited, and photogenerated electrons from its HOMO transfer rapidly to the CB of UiO-LP, effectively suppressing the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and enhancing light utilization efficiency. For the α-alkylation reaction, diethylbromomalonate, with a half reduction potential of −0.73 V vs. NHE in CH3CN [8], is reduced to generate an alkyl radical through a single-electron reduction process. Control experiments showed that only a trace amount of the product was obtained when 2.0 equivalents of the radical scavenger 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl (TEMPO) were added under standard reaction conditions, indicating the involvement of radical species in the reaction (Table S2, entry 9). Subsequently, the alkyl radical reacts with the enamine intermediate b formed via condensation of the aldehyde with the L-proline moiety in UiO-LP, yielding the radical intermediate c. The radical intermediate undergoes single-electron oxidation to form the iminium cation d, which upon hydrolysis yields the final alkylation product. Upon visible-light irradiation, the dehydrogenative cross-coupling reaction is initiated through the reduction of O₂ to [O₂]•⁻. Simultaneously, an enamine intermediate is generated via condensation between N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinoline and the ketone, accompanied by dehydration (Fig. 9b). The N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinoline then undergoes single-electron oxidation at the valence band of UiO-LP-EY. The resulting radical cation is subsequently attacked by the superoxide radical ( [O₂]•⁻), which abstracts a hydrogen atom, yielding an iminium ion intermediate and [OOH]⁻. This iminium ion is nucleophilically attacked by the enamine intermediate, forming a new iminium species. Hydrolysis of this intermediate releases the final coupling product and a proton (H⁺), while regenerating the catalyst. The proton is captured by [OOH]⁻ to form H₂O₂, which then decomposes into H₂O and O₂, thereby closing the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the UiO-MOF based bifunctional photo-organo catalysts were successfully developed by facile in-situ introduction of L-proline followed by solvothermal incorporation of photocatalytic functions. These catalysts are active under visible light irradiation at room temperature for the photoredox α-alkylation of aldehydes and cross-dehydrogenative coupling of N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinolines with ketones. UiO-LP-EY exhibited the highest catalytic activities, affording alkylation and coupling products in excellent yields with enantioselectivities comparable to the corresponding homogeneous catalytic systems. Importantly, enhanced synergy between the two kinds of catalytic active sites in bifunctional catalysts, led to significantly higher catalytic activity compared to the homogeneous counterpart. Furthermore, these catalysts demonstrated broad substrate scope and excellent recyclability. Based on the experimental results, plausible combined photo-organocatalytic mechanisms for the two reactions were proposed. coredata.dc:description: The development of highly efficient and recyclable bifunctional photoredox catalysts is extremely promising for organic synthesis. In this study, a novel kind of bifunctional metal-organic framework (MOF) based catalysts were prepared through the in-situ incorporation of the L-proline moiety into the MOF network and followed by the anchoring of dye molecules via a solvothermal process. These catalysts exhibited versatile catalytic activity in the visible light triggered α-alkylation of aldehydes and cross-dehydrogenative coupling reactions between N-aryl tetrahydroquinolines and ketones. The control experiments revealed enhanced synergy existed between the two kinds of catalytic active centers confined in the porous framework, resulting in significantly enhanced catalytic activities while maintaining comparable enantioselectivities to the corresponding homogeneous catalytic systems. Furthermore, the bifunctional catalysts showed high stability and reusability over five consecutive cycles with only a slight decrease in activity. Based on the experimental results, a plausible reaction mechanism over the present bifunctional catalyst was proposed.
